documents.title: and that 's all ¦ sebastian faulks signs off
text: guardian contributor sebastianfaulks 28 september 2016 2:04pm thank you very much to everyone who sent in questions .
i 'm sorry my answers are rather serious but that was really dictated by the tone of what you asked !
i am talking about where my heart used to beat at henley on saturday 1 october , and at cheltenham on saturday 8 october .
on a lighter note , i also have a new book of parodies out in october .
it called pistache returns .
there are a few jokes in there .

documents.title: 'i have grave misgivings about the whole question of biography '
text: alexwent asks : as a reader more and more inclined to non-fiction , i very much enjoyed the fatal englishman .
have you ever thought of writing biography again , and which subject might you choose ?
guardian contributor sebastianfaulks 28 september 2016 2:02pm thank you very much .
the brief answer is no .
i have grave misgivings about the whole question of biography , beyond a 30-page character sketch , a `` schilling life '' , or a well researched newspaper profile .

but i was asked if i would write a biography of the singer nick drake and i very much wish the request had come in time to make a fourth part of the fatal englishman , where it would have sat very well .
naranjilla asks : walking in one of the american cemeteries in normandy recently , i stumbled on the grave of one bill sargeant pfc 121 inf 8 div , arkansas sept 10 1944 .
would this be the same bill who provided inspiration for the character in where my heart used to beat ?
if so , did you first chance upon bill in the same way that i did ?
had you already found inspiration for his character from other sources ?

i would love to know ¦ if all of the principal world war one characters in that book have a real-life basis and whether they are also found at the same cemetery , or at other locations in northern france .

guardian contributor sebastianfaulks 28 september 2016 1:59pm baffled by this one i 'm afraid , as there is no-one called bill or sargeant , indeed no-one from the us army , in where my heart used to beat .
one of two of the details of fighting in north africa i borrowed from an unpublished memoir by my father , who fought with the first battalion , the duke of wellington 's regiment .
it was quite good on what was in your kit bag , that sort of thing .
but the characters are all their own men , or women , and all of them are invented .

documents.title: sibling rivalry ? story of my life !
text: nepthsolem asks : what are your thoughts about sibling rivalry ?
guardian contributor sebastianfaulks 28 september 2016 1:56pm i have nothing to say about this because i know my sisters will have said it much better than i can .
story of my life !
adajarndyce asks : at a book event i attended , you said you felt privileged to be able to make a living from writing .
do you think it is tougher today for writers to earn a crust than years ago ?
( just read [ george gissing 's ] new grub street ! )
if so , why , and could some things be done to produce a better climate and fairer deal ?
how can we encourage new writing ?
guardian contributor sebastianfaulks 28 september 2016 1:54pm it has always been next to impossible for serious writers to earn a living by their books .
but that need not be a problem .
most of them have always had other jobs , or are married to , or live with , people who make a living .
perhaps only twice in the last years of the 19th century , with the boom in universal literacy , and in the last years of the 20th century with the revolution in bookselling , has it been possible .
but that boom is well and truly over .
it does n't make much different to the author whether the book is sold in paper or as an e-book .
the problem is that the overall number is down , for the simple reason that there is so much competition for people 's attention .
for instance , i have at least 30 boxsets which friends of mine have told me are the greatest things ever shown or made .
because i still read books , i will never have the time to see any of them .
other people choose differently .
but on the plus side , people can now publish their own books for very little money and call themselves a published writer .
i 'm sure that in future the market will find a way of distributing and promoting those books if they feel , as in the case of fifty shades of grey , they can make a lot of money out of them .
the best way to encourage new writing is to make sure that children and young people are exposed all the time to good old writing .
this should happen at school and at home but there are also great enterprises like first story , which do their best to encourage .

documents.title: `` the 20th century has proved far bloodier than most of us foresaw ''
text: anna page asks : i have just finished where my heart used to beat for a book club .
robert feels the last century was a catastrophe in human terms , but i think the book offers hope for the future .
do you see the wars at the start of this century being as futile as those at the beginning of the last ?
guardian contributor sebastianfaulks 28 september 2016 1:47pm i 'm glad that you feel there is a sense of hope at the end of the book .
i could see very little myself , but quite a lot of people have said this to me , so perhaps there is something that i am not aware of .
i think it may lie in the fact that the main character does at least finally understand who he is and where he has come from .
my fear is that many of the wars so far this century are still related to the first world war , and the reordering of the great empires , particularly in the middle east .
my second fear is that some of them have a religious element , and the last thing war needs is an irrational fury .
on the other hand there is far greater international communication and co-operation through the un , nato and the eu .
in the catastrophic months leading up to august 1914 , our foreign secretary never left london .
that level of non-communication is now unthinkable .
but the aftermath of the 20th century has proved so far much bloodier than most of us foresaw .
dreamecho asks : many years ago , i heard you say there was a musical link between birdsong and charlotte gray .
i never could work it out .
can you enlighten us ?

guardian contributor sebastianfaulks 28 september 2016 1:42pm it 's a long time now , but my recollection is that a character called berard sings an embarrassing song about a little boat early on in birdsong .
i think , but you 'd need to check , that the same song is sung by a group of resistance fighters before they go out to a parachute drop in charlotte grey .
lucotter asks : is there a rejuvenation or therapeutic sort of review of earlier life when a novelist is creating rich plausibilities in a character around a generation or so younger than they are ?
i 'm thinking particularly of [ stephen ] wraysford and the trauma that the mature authorial voice has such kindly wisdom for .
i 'm grateful for the sincere pleasures of teaching birdsong to sixth-formers after an interval of about a decade .
i 'm finding the difference in my own response to sw over time remarkable .
guardian contributor sebastianfaulks 28 september 2016 1:40pm thank you very much .
i was only 39 when i wrote the book , and stephen is almost 30 by the end , so i was n't quite a different generation .
and he is pretty grown up for his age .
it is very interesting to revisit young characters in fiction .
i have just read the catcher in the rye for the fifth time with roughly eight year intervals , and for the fifth time i see holden and his story completely differently .
i had never really noticed how argumentative , difficult and even violent he is .
i am currently finding a voice for a 17-year-old boy with a north african background .
apart from double-checking a few cultural and religious references , i am very much enjoying the liberation of writing in the voice of someone with no knowledge of and no interest in history .

in the course of the book , he will encounter people with a different understanding of life but it is fun to write in the person of someone who thinks only about sex and food and where he is going to spend the night .
oleksandrok asks : what is your favourite movie ?
guardian contributor sebastianfaulks 28 september 2016 1:36pm i enjoyed sideways .
i like those slightly offbeat , slightly arty but nevertheless mainstream american comedies , none of whose names i can now remember .
my favourite as a child was journey to the centre of the earth , with james mason and pat boone - the dinosaurs were thrilling !
even though you could see they were just small lizards magnified .

documents.title: do i look like hadrian ? andrew motion thought so
text: groundhogday asks : has anyone ever commented how closely you resemble the roman emperor hadrian ?
guardian contributor sebastianfaulks 28 september 2016 1:33pm yes .
andrew motion kindly sent me a postcard from the british museum exhibition a few years ago .
in my younger and slimmer days , i was also often compared to the american tennis player vitas gerulaitis .
hadrian v faulks ¦ any similarity ?
nso995 asks : how do you feel about birdsong being used as a set text for public exams ?

is it gratifying or frustrating that a number of students ( including me ) had to answer in an as-level exam a question along the lines of : write about the ways faulks tells the story in chapter one of birdsong ?
guardian contributor sebastianfaulks 28 september 2016 1:32pm i am sorry if the questions were boring , and put you off the book .
but of course , i personally am very happy to see it read by young people .
most of those who have written to me or spoken to me about it were able to enjoy something in the book far beyond the annoying requirements of a-level .
i would hope that its quite traditional use of characterisation and examination of the interplay between public and private worlds would enable students to appreciate other books of this kind .
however , i do n't think it should be read by anyone under the age of 16 .

documents.title: `` good writing is as bare as hemingway or as ornate as proust â so long as it works ''
text: goldendays49 asks : has our desire for good writing destroyed the idea for a rattling good read ?
guardian contributor sebastianfaulks 28 september 2016 1:29pm i do n't think so .
but i think `` good writing '' is becoming rather niche , a sort of genre rather like crime , or romance .
it depends how you make your divisions .

in france for instance , the big distinction is between `` literature '' which may or may not be fiction , but has no character development or plot to speak of , or any traditional novelistic attribute and what they call `` fiction '' , which is anything with a story from conrad to el james .
so you can make any number of category divisions horizontally or vertically .
my idea of good writing , by the way , is writing which most effectively articulates the themes of the book .
it can be as bare as hemingway or as ornate as proust , so long as it works .

documents.title: people have lost even more trust in the political class
text: bushofghosts asks : if you were writing a state-of-the-nation novel today , what aspect of our nation 's life would you be drawn to ?
what would you find most emblematic of our current state ?
guardian contributor sebastianfaulks 28 september 2016 1:24pm i feel that a week in december touched on the issues which are still important today .

we have not yet recovered from the crimes and misdemeanours of the financial sector that led to the crash , but i think the political focus is now simply on trying to make some of these people pay a fair amount of tax .
no progress seems yet to have been made .
the idea of a society atomised into small sections , many of which depend on a virtual world whether of finance , the internet , religion or psychosis still seems to me the characteristic problem .
i 'm afraid it 's much easier for novelists to dramatise than to offer practical solutions .
but of course , everything begins with education , and that would be a good place to start .
one thing that has changed is that people have lost even more trust in the political class .
and we are now a country with an unpopular and unelected leadership , and no formal opposition .
so there is the banana republic element to add into the mix .
stevensmall asks : when writing , how much of the story is planned and how much evolves as you write ?
guardian contributor sebastianfaulks 28 september 2016 1:18pm every book is different .
with engleby , i had no idea what was going to happen .
a week in december was very meticulously planned with a lot of word counting and word processing .
but usually , i have a rough route map - i know that i 'm going , for instance , from london to tehran and i know that i will pass through geneva , milan , athens etc .
but i do n't feel i need to know all the villages and waystations along the way .
this is where you hope , in that slightly fey way that writers talk about , that the characters will come alive and come to your assistance .
also , i continue to research parts of a novel even after i 've started writing .
and the research itself will often throw up ideas for incident and character , as well as maybe confirming their facts .
for instance , in on green dolphin street , i went to a lot of old-fashioned bars and diners in new york trying to find the atmosphere of the late 50s .
i was struck by how much meat was eaten in these places , so frank turned out to have been brought up near the stockyards in chicago .
id218177 asks : i read birdsong when it was first published .
how did you do the research into the tunnellers ?
i think it is a terrific book , and it inspired me to find out more about my grandad 's experience in world war one .
i found out he was in the rga at messines ridge .
guardian contributor sebastianfaulks 28 september 2016 1:13pm the tunnellers are very important , because i felt that while going over this territory i needed to tell people something new .
i first came across the tunnellers in a book published in 1988 called war underground .
there was n't much else in print so i based my researches on documents in the imperial war museum .
a great deal more has come to light in the years since then , and indeed whole tunnel systems have been discovered on the western front .
once you are aware of the miners you will see references to them even in famous books like goodbye to all that .
it 's just that no-one had gone underground with them in detail in a novel .

i was drawn to them for two reasons : one because their story seemed almost untold , and secondly , because the idea of this underground hell contained within a greater hell , seemed to me to have great symbolic force .
kj tham writes : i 'm currently doing an analysis on the last night , an extract from your novel charlotte gray .
i would like to ask if there were any inspirations from your personal life that inspired you to write it .
or if your personal experiences had affected your viewpoints on certain issues brought up in that passage ?
many thanks , a sleep deprived igcse student .
guardian contributor sebastianfaulks 28 september 2016 1:10pm i would love to help with this question , but i 'm not sure which bit you mean by `` the last night '' .
let me know if you can and i will tell you !
pastavist asks : my whole family loved where my heart used to beat .
was john fowles ' the magus perhaps an influence ?
which current or recent writers in english do you most enjoy ?
guardian contributor sebastianfaulks 28 september 2016 1:09pm thank you very much .
i 'm glad you were n't put off by the terrible sadness of the book !
yes , i did have the magus in mind , to some extent .
it was one of a number of books from that period that i re-read .
i thought it stood up pretty well except that he did n't know how to end the story .
i think the influence of the magus is in the central conversation between two men which gradually peels off the layers of history to reach the central trauma .
among the writers i like today are alan hollinghurst , and the american george saunders .
also lorrie moore .
i 'm about to read ann patchett when my wife has finished with it .
i 'm not sure the collector was an influence on engleby , although i have read and enjoyed it very much when it came out .
engleby more or less wrote itself , and i do n't think mike will have had much time for `` influence '' .
mythicalmagpie asks : i very much enjoyed birdsong .
the story of the tunnels built deep below enemy trenches was fascinating .
will there be any lesser known facts about the second world war in where my heart used to beat ?

guardian contributor sebastianfaulks 28 september 2016 1:05pm i think the descriptions of fighting in tunisia and at anzio cover parts of the war that are very little known about , compared to d-day and so on .
d-day was much more decisive in terms of recapturing paris and france , whereas the recapture of rome was strategically less important .
but the conditions at anzio were as bad as anything in the first world war , and it was a terrible slander that some people referred to the troops who fought there as `` d-day dodgers '' .
but i suppose i 'm really trying to reveal what it must have felt like more than to dig up some aspect of the war that is completely unknown .
sebastian has pen in hand and is ready to go .
follow along below .
faulks at the guardian 's london office .
beaumont-thomas

documents.title: post your questions for sebastian faulks
text: with his tales of romance , duty and war , sebastian faulks has amassed fans of both literary fiction and blockbuster historical e breaking through with birdsong in 1993 following a successful career in journalism he deputy-edited the independent on sunday for a period his novels have stayed on bestseller lists ever since .
he has written well-received official sequels to james bond and jeeves and wooster , while his 1999 novel charlotte grey was adapted into a movie with cate blanchett .
he returns to its second world war setting with his most recent work , where my heart used to beat , which charts a life lived through the horrors of the italian trenches and out the other side .

with the book out in paperback this month , sebastian is joining us to answer your questions about anything in his career , in a live webchat from 1pm on wednesday 28 september post them in the comments below , and he 'll answer as many as possible .
